DataElement.preferredName: Demographic Patient Industry United States Bureau of Census Industry Code
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Code for the patient's usual industry, using U.S. Census Bureau codes (2000 Census is preferable) according to coding procedures recommended for death certificates.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: statistical characterization of human populations (or segments of human populations broken down by age or sex or income etc.).

Concepts.definition: The statistical characterization of human populations or segments of human populations (e.g., characterization by age, sex, race, or income).

Property.preferredDefinition: A person who requires medical care.:The aggregate of manufacturing or technically productive enterprises in a particular field, often named after its principle product, as "the automobile industry", "the steel industry". It includes the ownership and management of companies, factories, industrial plants, etc. (From Random House Unabridged Dictionary, 2d ed)C0021267: Industry

Concepts.definition: A person who receives medical attention, care, or treatment, or who is registered with medical professional or institution with the purpose to receive medical care when necessary.
The people or companies engaged in a particular kind of commercial enterprise; the organized action of making of goods and services for sale.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: The distinguishing qualities or prominent aspect of a person, object, action, process, or substance.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Conceptual entities required by NCI operations and systems. Includes administrative, financial, organizational and quasi-scientific concepts required for NCI operations and systems.

ReferenceDocuments.name: NAACCR Data Dictionary
ReferenceDocuments.description: North American Association of Central Cancer Registries, Standards for Cancer Registries, Volume II, Data Standards and Data Dictionary, Eleventh Edition, Version 11.1

ReferenceDocuments.name: Census Industry Code Description
ReferenceDocuments.description: Use U.S. Census Bureau codes (2000 Census is preferable) according to coding procedures recommended for death certificates.  This data item applies only to patients who are age 14 years or older at the time of diagnosis.
